column2:
City Corporation issued a boil order Wednesday night for the following areas: East of North Arkansas Avenue, West of Sparksford Drive, South of Darby Lane and North of Aspen Lane.

The order, issued at 8:45 p.m. Wednesday, is a precautionary measure because of the possibility contaminated water may have entered the distribution system as the result of a 12-inch water main rupture on Aspen Lane.

Because of the same incident, the Tri-County Regional Water Distribution District has also issued a boil order in neighboring areas, including from Sparksford Drive to State Highway 124, Field Street and Aspen Lane.

Under a boil order, all affected customers are advised that the water may be unsafe for human consumption. Water used for drinking or food preparation must be boiled briskly for one minute prior to use. City Corporation recommends discarding all ice cubes and using boiled water for making ice.

The boil order will be lifted by the Arkansas Department of Health (ADH) when a set of bacteriological samples taken on consecutive days indicate the water is free of bacteriological contamination and an adequate disinfectant level is established throughout the distribution system.

Oakview community still under boil order
Updated: Thu 9:34 AM, Feb 09, 2012

column2: var Title = ""Oakview community still under boil order "";

column1: MARSHALL COUNTY, OK -- After a week-long boil order hundreds of Marshall county residents say they are concerned about the safety of their water. They want to know why they are not getting straight answers from the water company.

When I spoke with officials at the Department of Environmental Quality they said a sample done about two weeks ago in the Oakview area tested positive for E. coli, but residents said their water company told them a completely different story.
More than 900 residents who live in the Oakview area have been under a Boil Order for a week now.
""We're cooking all day long, water, to wash dishes, to cook with, and to somehow take a bath with"" said Mitchell.
Inge Mitchell lives in the Oakview area and said she heard about the boil order from a neighbor. But when that neighbor contacted Oakview water corporation they told her the water was okay.
""They were told the water is fine, you're exaggerating, but we find out different"" said Mitchell.

Skylar McElhaney with DEQ said several follow up water samples taken since the original sample tested positive for E. coli on January 25th have also tested positive for total coliform bacteria. In the week since the boil order was issued Oak View Water Corporation was bought by Texoma Water, LLC. We tried to get in touch with the new owner--but our calls were not answered so we contacted previous owner, Lois Sullivan, to ask how the bacteria got into the water. She told us the water is not contaminated but refused an on camera interview.

""When we do lift that advisory we will issue another press release to notify the public that it is okay to consume that water but for now we recommend that residents continue to vigorously boil the water for at least one minute"" Said McElhaney from DEQ.

Oakview resident Carol Davis said she is upset because she is paying more for the water she can not use. When she called to find out why her latest water bill increased by $6 Oakview water corporation told her the company had been sold.
""We weren't told that it was going to be sold we weren't told that it wasn't drinkable water we weren't told the prices were going to be raised we haven't been told anything"" said Davis.

Boil Water Notice: Etoile Water Supply customers who live in Shirley Creek Estates
NACOGDOCHES CO., TX (KTRE) – A boil water notice is in effect until further notice for customers of Etoile Water Supply who live in Shirley Creek Estates.
The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) required the notice after a line break was discovered in the system on February 1.

The notice states, ""To ensure destruction of all harmful bacteria and other microbes, water for drinking, cooking, and making ice should be boiled and cooled prior to use. The water should be brought to a vigorous, rolling boil and then boiled for two minutes. In lieu of boiling, you may purchase bottled water or obtain water from some other suitable source.""

Once the line has been repaired and the water tested and approved for consumption the boil water notice will be lifted.  Until then if you have questions concerning this matter, you may contact Charlie Luse at (936)854-2215.

Junction City lifts boil water advisory
<!-- Sets shortStory JS variable for DFP targeting -->

Junction City has rescinded a boil water advisory that had been in place since Monday.

Laboratory tests and other factors indicate the water now is safe for drinking and other uses, the city said in a news release. The advisory affected customers on the west side of Spring Valley Road, north of Wildcat Lane and south of Buddy Drive in the Olivia Farms development.

The advisory was put in place because of a water main break that resulted in a loss of pressure and could have led to contamination.

The city's health director plays a number of important roles in the community.

Those can range from working with other agencies through the Healthy Gloucester Collaborative to teaming up with emergency services and getting word out to the public regarding a potential health crisis — like the three-week boil-water order of 2009.

But new city Health Director Noreen Burke brings added expertise to the table from her previous position in Somerville, where she served as head of the city's Human Rights Commission and then, more recently, as public health director.

To that end, Burke noted that she views public health through a larger, ""human rights"" lens. That means advocating for and ensuring that all residents of the city have equal access to good public health — regardless of the kind of house in which they live, which schools the children may attend, or what kind of food families can afford. And she said she's taken her first weeks in town to learn Gloucester's social and economic nature, and how that affects the health of its residents.

Burke, who came on board last month, says she doesn't yet have any new initiatives for the city's Health Department at this point, other than to focus on the Get Fit Gloucester project and other efforts the department is already coordinating. But her background already suggests that she's aware and committed to tackling the preventive health and health care needs of all Gloucester residents. And that's a good calling card.

We welcome her to Gloucester, and wish her nothing but the best.

A lateral break in an Ozark water line early morning Feb. 4
caused a handful of residents to be without water or with very low
water pressure. Residents located in the north water plane are
encouraged to boil water used for drinking. However, Larry Martin,
Ozark Public Works director, said DNR did not and will not issue a
“There’s no boil order. DNR did not issue one and there’s no
intention to do so,” he said. “Since the water was down, even
though only in a very small part of town, I issued an
The water line break was discovered about 2 a.m. Feb. 4 on 22nd
Street, affecting people located between Garton Road, 22nd Street,
“Unfortunately it was a very deep section of line,” Martin said
about the break. “It was a lateral break in a line versus something
you could patch. It had to be cut out and removed, so it was a very
According to the advisory, found on the city website,
is recommended that drinking water should be vigorously boiled for
one to three minutes for infants and those with compromised immune
Martin said routine samples were taken this morning, Feb. 6, and
sent to a private lab. He expects to receive the results Feb. 7 and
plans to lift the boil advisory.
Martin said his crew did a “great job” and attributes the
SCADA—Supervisory Control And Data Acquisition—system for the early
“Due to the supervisory control system, we knew about it early
on. The SCADA system gave us perhaps a four to five hour head start
on addressing the problem,” he said.

Boil water notice rescinded for Bell-Milam-Falls WSC customers
By Christine McCarthy
CENTRAL TEXAS- Customers of Bell-Milam-Falls Water Supply Corporation no longer need to boil water.
The company rescinded the notice Saturday after instruction from the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.
A water line break in mid-January caused concern there might have been contaminants in the water supply.
Customers with questions should call company representative, Robert Jekel at 254-697-4106, or TCEQ at 512-239-4691.

The Toho Water Authority is advising residents to boil water ater a water main ruptured in Kissimmee.
Authorities said the repair has been made, but residents in the Lake Tivoli Apartments and Bella Vista Condominiums are being advised to boil their water for the time being.
Approximately 400 residents are located in the affected area, authorities said.
Get email alerts for local stories and events around the world.
Residents should boil their water prior to consumption as a precautionary measure.
A vigorous boil for one minute is adequate to make water safe for drinking.
As an alternative bottled water may be used.
The boil water alert will be in effect until a bacteriological survey shows that the water is safe to drink at which time the boil water alert will be lifted by the Toho Water Authority.
Residents with questions are asked to call the water authority at  407-944-5000.

Water Boil Advisory for Three Rivers
3:47 AM. CST February 06, 2012
<span class=""inline-share-btn inline-share-btn-facebook share-button facebook"" data-tealium-share="""" data-tealium-tracker=""inline_facebook"">
<a class=""inline-share-btn inline-share-btn-twitter share-button twitter"" data-tealium-share="""" data-tealium-tracker=""inline_twitter"">

The City of Three Rivers has issued a water boil advisory after a water main break on Thursday.  The city's storage tank levels have dropped below the pressure allowed by the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality's standards.  

TCEQ requires residents to bring water to a vigorous boil for 2 minutes prior to drinking, cooking and making ice.  Boiling the water will ensure that bacteria and other harmful microbes are destroyed.

TCEQ will monitor the situation in Three Rivers and city officials will alert residents when the water boil advisory is lifted.
